executive_summary: Charities and endowments enjoyed donors with full pockets as billions of dollars sloshed around a booking world economy. Donations depend heavily on wealth, consumer confidence and charitable organizations.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Life Science Stands Out as a Popular Cause for Donating
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 stunted donation flows early on. Donating resumed as pandemic cautions eased and people realized how many Americans faced challenging situations. MacKenzie Scott donated $4.0 billion to coronavirus relief, significantly contributing to the total amount donated.
The wealthy consistently donate to charity, while most of the population donates sporadically. Charitable contributions from the middle-class move in line with disposable income levels.

Wealthy individuals donate to long-term projects, like Mark Zuckerberg's $3.4 billion donation to a 10-year effort to study the biological processes in humans. Environmental conservation efforts receive similar gifts for long-term projects.

Instead of donating, leaving the government to backstop the social fallout faced by many. Donations flowed in as pandemic concerns eased. The widespread need for food and necessities encouraged donations to support those affected by the pandemic.

Economic reopening lifted asset prices, wealth and donations in 2021. The fast turnaround led to asset and goods inflation, forcing the Federal Reserve to begin raising interest rates in 2022. This has since killed asset prices and donations. In 2023, revenue for donations, grants and endowments continued to decline, falling 0.4%. Revenue has climbed at a CAGR of 1.5% in the past five years to reach $169.2 billion with profit of 12.6%.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Weak Asset Prices Hold Back Donations
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Donations move in tandem with corporate profit and individual wealth. The S&P 500 will struggle early on in the next five years. Stock prices come with significant volatility. Asset prices, in general, will struggle and keep donation levels moderate.

Earnings improve when foundations receive more contributions and investment income than they pay out in donations and grants. Investment returns determine profitability. Lower returns will weaken profitability and prevent earnings from rising.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Governments Facing Financial Woes Rely on Charities to Support Those in Need
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Donation revenue will dry up while the level of need remains consistent. People will always encounter poverty, natural disasters or health challenges and need support. Charities will have the same amount of work to do with fewer resources.

Governments face crippling debt going into the next five years and continue borrowing at higher interest rates. Some fiscal responsibility may force governments to pull back support for charitable causes, putting even more pressure on foundations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Loyal Support for Specific Causes Ensures a Net Rise in Donations
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Education remains the primary instrument that shapes a society's economic and social well-being. Foundations will continue to support organizations that promote educational opportunities for individuals who otherwise lack access to quality education.

industry_definition: This industry comprises organizations known as grantmaking foundations or charitable trusts. Operators award grants from trust funds based on a competitive selection process or by the preferences of the foundation managers and grantors. Industry operators may also fund a single entity, such as a museum or university. Due to the unique structure of this industry, revenue is calculated by adding contributions, grants, investment income and realized gains.
key_trends: Donations sway up and down with asset prices. Interest rates push money out of stocks, lowering investment income for endowments and potential donors.
Education and healthcare remain the key focuses of the most prominent foundations. In recent years, life science and environmental preservation have attracted high-profile donors and more funding.
Foundations must pay out at least 5.0% of total assets for charitable purposes. Most assets remain tied up in financial markets, while only a portion goes to grants and donations.
Foundations often work with government and corporate organizations on charitable initiatives. The Biden administration's recent Economic Opportunity Coalition exemplifies this, bringing

assistance_points.assistance_description: The Council of Foundations, a membership organization with more than 1,600 foundations and corporate giving programs, represents foundations.
The Foundation Center supports foundations similarly.

market_segmentation.segment_description: While goals and approaches vary, educational organizations strive to strengthen educational systems to expand career opportunities for individuals. Efforts stem from the belief that quality education helps people succeed later in life.

Foundations use grant money to improve healthcare quality or develop policies and programs to expand health coverage to those unable to afford it. Other organizations can provide children access to affordable healthy foods and improved physical activities in schools and communities to fight childhood obesity.

Human services organizations provide several services to individuals and communities, including food assistance, housing, employment training, childcare, and youth mentoring. According to a Harris Poll conducted for Fast Company, hunger relief experienced the most charitable giving during the pandemic, with 34.0% of poll respondents contributing to hunger relief causes.

The public affairs and society benefit segment covers grants to organizations primarily engaged in civic, community and societal improvement projects. These projects can include philanthropy and voluntarism, community improvement, science and technology research, civil rights projects and social science research.
Organizations use art and culture grants in myriad ways, including access and upkeep for museums and archival collections, advancing art conservation and enhancing arts education.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Organizations Create Numerous Grants to Fit Different Foundations' Needs
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The grant type determines the grant specifications, like how to spend the awarded funds. Organizations must spend funds according to the foundation's specifications based on the grant type.

business_locations.location_description: Elevated poverty rates in the Southeast make it a prime destination for charities and grant-making organizations. Foundations can support education and employment initiatives, particularly for immigrants coming into Florida. Low taxes in the Southeast encourage smaller non-profits already benefiting from tax breaks to set up shop. Endowments struggle mostly with capital gains taxes earned from selling financial assets, which fall under federal jurisdiction.

The West's large high-net-worth population draws in grant-making institutions. Major companies working in technology and entertainment rake in earnings for donations to charitable initiatives. California houses Silicon Valley and innovative research institutions like Cal Tech. Grant-making organizations fund researchers in technology and science through universities and think tanks.

New York serves as the financial capital of the United States. Endowments and grant-making institutions take advantage of New York's financial institutions, research companies and universities. Like the Southeast, the Mid-Atlantic brings in many immigrants who need charitable support. Foundations supporting immigrants and working abroad work through influential New York-based international institutions, like the United Nations.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) considers every US and foreign charity that qualifies as tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code as a private foundation unless it demonstrates to the IRS that it falls into another category.

The IRS requires independent and corporate foundations to annually pay at least 5.0% of their net assets from the preceding year to charitable causes. Independent and corporate foundations must pay an excise tax of 1.0% or 2.0% on their earnings and provide grants only to other 501(c)(3) organizations, with a few rare exceptions.

Grant-making foundations have restrictions on grant disbursement. Some foundations restrict making grants only to specific causes or geographic areas, while others enjoy broad discretion. Foundations also create their own limits on how grant recipients spend the funds.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Bringing in volunteers for field work helps ease labor costs
barriers_points.barrier_description: Bringing in volunteers for field work helps ease labor costs. Managing the foundation's books requires skilled workers. Young foundations typically outsource accounting and financial advising.

basis_points.basis_title: Partnerships have similar benefits to mergers
basis_points.basis_description: Partnerships have similar benefits to mergers, like expanding asset pools, accessing new donors, reaching new geographies and demographics and creating cost synergies.

basis_points.basis_title: Impact investing gives people an avenue to support companies that benefit society
basis_points.basis_description: Impact investing gives people an avenue to support companies that benefit society. Many still prefer donating to foundations because the donation has a more apparent impact.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Mergers can help foundations and grant-giving organizations scale by expanding brand name recognition, which leads to greater donation levels, and asset holdings, which provide more significant interest and dividend payouts each year. Despite possible benefits, mergers don't drive significant trends for foundations. Merging non-profits must ensure proper due diligence to flag any changes to non-profit status. Organizations find that partnerships are easier to manage, which brings similar benefits to mergers.

Most charitable foundations focus a significant portion of their giving on local causes. This leaves plenty of space in the market for foundations to coexist. The myriad of philanthropic causes, domestically and internationally, ensures that organizations can easily find a niche.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Foundations purchase computers and office equipment for headquarters. Most funds for purchases go to field equipment, depending on the charity, including toys and sports equipment, healthcare equipment, books or food items.
Outside fund management fees also account for a significant revenue share, as most foundations outsource asset management and custodial services.

Charitable foundations don't require a significant labor force. Most organizations maintain a small number of permanent staff and supplement the remainder of labor needs with volunteers to keep operational costs low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Foundations derive a significant share of income from investment returns. Asset prices play an outsized role in revenue volatility.
Donors' willingness to give up money fluctuates with the economic outlook.

FAQs.question: Are contributions reliant on the overall health of the US economy? What measures do you take to ensure financial health, even during periods of economic uncertainty?
FAQs.answer: Donations from individuals are derived from their disposable income. Household disposable income is influenced by taxes, interest rates and employment opportunities, among other factors. Drops in real household disposable income negatively impact the level of donations to organizations.

FAQs.question: Do you market your organization's activities online to generate increased contributions? Does your organization use any social media platforms to do this?
FAQs.answer: Publicizing the work and plans of your charitable organization can entice others to contribute.

FAQs.question: How does your organization respond to fluctuations in the stock market?
FAQs.answer: Most grantmaking institutions rely on dividends earned from investment in equities to fund disbursements, program delivery and further asset.

FAQs.question: How does your organization compensate for volatile profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Profit comprises any excess funding after program activities are funded. Profit can be volatile, but since industry operators do not exist to optimize their profit it is not a valuable measure of financial measurement.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?

FAQs.question: How do you keep track of the company's expenditures? Are there any systems you can use to effectively control costs?
FAQs.answer: Grantmakers must maintain a well-diversified portfolio that provides interest and dividend payments capable of supporting grantmaking and asset accumulation.

FAQs.question: How loyal is your customer base? How much of your donations are reliant on repeat donors?
FAQs.answer: Organizations that have a high level of regard in the community will be better positioned to carry out work and allocate financial resources to the most.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among donors and grantees? What methods do you use to communicate your performance and reliability to the public?
FAQs.answer: Organizations must have a good reputation to ensure a healthy flow of donations and support for the programs that they administer. Individuals are more likely to donate to organizations that they feel will use their money wisely.

FAQs.question: Does your organization experience lower funding during periods of lower corporate profit? How can you entice companies to spend when corporate profit is low?
FAQs.answer: Many large- and medium-size businesses are active donors to grantmaking foundations, and some operators even run their own foundations. These businesses are both more willing and able to donate to industry operators when earnings are high.

FAQs.question: Do you expect more donations as disposable income levels rise? How do you stimulate demand when disposable income levels are low?
FAQs.answer: Household disposable income is influenced by taxes, interest rates and employment opportunities, among other factors. Drops in real household disposable income negatively affect the level of donations to industry organizations.

FAQs.question: Does your organization monitor equity markets and the S&P 500? What share of your funding is dependent on investment income generated from equities?
FAQs.answer: Improvements in equities markets serve to increase assets for industry operators, enabling them to provide more donations and grants. Moreover, wealth gains from stock market improvements also tend to increase donations from businesses and individuals.
